text: Has anyone had any resoundingly good or shockingly bad experiences with publisher/media companies spin off in house "Brand agencies". Along the lines of T brand by New York Times? I'm getting splinters sitting on the fence about them and love to hear content marketers take?

text:
I worked at a company where we had a thought leadership board that is similar to what you're creating. We played around with the weights to get it right. For example, a few people were able to get a lot of speaking gigs but everyone could do a blog post.

A couple challenges: People had to input their activity into a spreadsheet to generate the leaderboard, which required them to take an extra action and meant that it wasn't always up to date. We also had someone double check each item (since there was a $ incentive) and that was very time-consuming.

Overall, it was somewhat effective, but depends on buy-in.

elements.text:

We also had someone double check each item (since there was a $ incentive) and that was very time-consuming.

Overall, it was somewhat effective, but depends on buy-in.

text:
Hi friends,

I have a couple questions for the folks who've operated a contributor model, where you call for pitches from SMEs within and outside the company and either have those contributors write the content themselves or have a writer ghostwrite for them.

My questions are:
• What does your production workflow look like — starting from the call for pitches down to publishing?
• How do you source contributors and if they're incentivized how?
For context, majority of my experience has been with in-house and contract writers who produce content based on briefs and outlines.

elements.text:
Hi friends,

I have a couple questions for the folks who've operated a contributor model, where you call for pitches from SMEs within and outside the company and either have those contributors write the content themselves or have a writer ghostwrite for them.

My questions are:
What does your production workflow look like — starting from the call for pitches down to publishing?
How do you source contributors and if they're incentivized how?
For context, majority of my experience has been with in-house and contract writers who produce content based on briefs and outlines.

text:
Hi Ronnie,

In my experience, it largely varies depending on if the SME is an analyst (some people conflate these two) and if they're an employee of the company or not.

If the SME is an employee:
We have an industry marketer who is responsible for creating a go-to-market campaign plan that includes content.
They reach out to the SME within the company and start discussing the target audience, the strategic POV and topics to cover, while the industry marketer supplies the insight into which opportunities (from a product perspective) are most advantageous to pursue.
For contributing to a blog, SMEs may often have a an idea already. Otherwise, the industry marketer and SME work together to brainstorm a topic and go-to-market messaging, along with a CTA to an appropriate next step for the target audience.
We have a "blog brief" that helps contributors outline their blog, along with best practices and parameters, e.g. tone of voice, desired word count.
This brief then may come to a content writer who drafts a byline and then is reviewed by the SME for accuracy.
Our editorial manager then inputs the byline into our CMS (Wagtail) and schedules it for publishing with the SME named the author, their bio and headshot appears at the bottom of their contributed blog post as well.
We also supply the SME with social post copy for them to promote their byline through their social media profiles (not just the company's corporate social media accounts)

We source contributors from analyst firms, relevant speaking events within our industry, and sometimes through our network of c-level leadership. The analysts are pay-to-play, while others may be open to contributing in order to help boost their personal brand or to help promote a book they've recently published.

For contributing to a blog, SMEs may often have a an idea already. Otherwise, the industry marketer and SME work together to brainstorm a topic and go-to-market messaging, along with a CTA to an appropriate next step for the target audience.
We have a "blog brief" that helps contributors outline their blog, along with best practices and parameters, e.g. tone of voice, desired word count.
This brief then may come to a content writer who drafts a byline and then is reviewed by the SME for accuracy.
Our editorial manager then inputs the byline into our CMS (Wagtail) and schedules it for publishing with the SME named the author, their bio and headshot appears at the bottom of their contributed blog post as well.
